gpx_analysis package

Submodules

gpx_analysis.app module

This script contains the app class for the GPX analysis tool. Controls the GUI, MapHandler and more.

gpx_analysis.components module

This file contains functions used for doing geographic calculations

gpx_analysis.components.geo_distance(latitude1: float, longitude1: float, latitude2: float, longitude2: float) → float[source]

This function calculates the distance between two points in the world in meters

Parameters:

  • latitude1 – The latitude of the first point

  • longitude1 – The longitude of the first point

  • latitude2 – The latitude of the second point

  • longitude2 – The longitude of the second point

Returns:

The distance between the two points in meters

gpx_analysis.components.get_track_bounds(input_track: Track) → tuple[source]

Return the bounding regions of the track

Parameters:

input_track – The input track

Returns:

North latitude, east longitude, south latitude, west longitude

gpx_analysis.components.lighten_color(colour, amount=0.5)[source]

lightens a given rgb colour

Parameters:

  • colour – RGB tuple colour

  • amount – the lower the number below 0 the lighter

Returns:

An rgb colour lightened

gpx_analysis.components.standardise_gpx_distances(input_track: Track) → Track[source]

This function converts the original (lat lon) distances in the track into meters where 0,0 is bottom left of the track

Parameters:

input_track – The already parsed GPX class

Returns:

the modified track

gpx_analysis.components.union_bounds(bounds1: tuple, bounds2: tuple) → tuple[source]

Return the union of two bounds

Parameters:

  • bounds1 – The first bounds

  • bounds2 – The second bounds

Returns:

The union of the two bounds

gpx_analysis.gpx_parser module

This module parses a GPX file into the track class which is made up of track points (another new class).

Bases: object

This class represents a track in a GPX file.

gpx_analysis.graph_handler module

This module handles the graphing of the GPX file and the fetching of OSM tiles

class gpx_analysis.graph_handler.MapClass[source]

Bases: object

Class for converting scales between the GPX file and the graph

add_athlete(athlete_key: str, athlete_value: dict) → None[source]

Add a track to the graph handler instance

Parameters:

  • athlete_key – The key that gets added to the dictionary (simple filename)

  • athlete_value – The dict of athlete data

Returns:

None

center_viewpoint(positions: list[tuple[float, float]], offset: float = 0.1) → None[source]

This rebounds the viewpoint of the mpl figure so it includes all the boats and it’s roughly centered around them

Parameters:

  • positions – A list of the tuple (lat,lon) coordinates of the boats

  • offset – The border around the points (how zoomed it is) between 0 and 1

Returns:

None

Convert the degrees to the graph coordinates

Parameters:

degrees – The degrees to convert (lat,lon)

Returns:

The graph coordinates

draw_line(start: tuple[float, float], end: tuple[float, float], color: str = 'green', width: int = 2) → Line2D[source]

Draw a line on the graph

Parameters:

  • start – tuple lat,lon coordinates

  • end – tuple lat,lon coordinates

  • color – colour of the point default green

  • width – width of the line default 2

Returns:

the line data

draw_point(athlete_key: str, pos: tuple[float, float], color: str | tuple = 'green', size: float = 1) → None[source]

Draw a point on the graph

Parameters:

  • athlete_key – The key of the athlete whose marker we’re adding

  • pos – tuple (lat,lon) coordinates

  • color – colour of the point default green

  • size – radius of the point default 1

Returns:

None

Parameters:

input_value – input value between 0 and 1

Returns:

gpx_analysis.graph_handler.deg2num(lat_deg: float, lon_deg: float, zoom: int) → tuple[int, int][source]

Code for converting lat lon to tile number from https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Slippy_map_tilenames

Parameters:

  • lat_deg – Input latitude

  • lon_deg – Input longitude

  • zoom – OSM zoom level

Returns:

the OSM tile position

gpx_analysis.graph_handler.get_all_images_in_bounds(bounds) → dict[tuple, <module 'PIL.Image' from '/Users/edfillingham/Documents/Repos/GPX-Analysis/venv/lib/python3.11/site-packages/PIL/Image.py'>][source]

Get all the images in the bounds and put them in a dictionary with their tile index as the key

Parameters:

bounds – The bounds of the track (NESW)

Returns:

The collection of images as a dict key = image pos, value = image

gpx_analysis.graph_handler.get_all_images_near_track(track: Track) → dict[tuple, <module 'PIL.Image' from '/Users/edfillingham/Documents/Repos/GPX-Analysis/venv/lib/python3.11/site-packages/PIL/Image.py'>][source]

More Tile server friendly way of getting images, by only fetching the ones near the track

Parameters:

track – The track to get images of nearby

Returns:

The collection of images as a dict key = image pos, value = image

gpx_analysis.graph_handler.get_img(x_coord: int, y_coord: int, zoom: int)[source]

Get the image from the tile either from cache or downloading

Parameters:

  • x_coord – The x tile index

  • y_coord – The y tile index

  • zoom – The zoom tile index

Returns:

The image

gpx_analysis.graph_handler.num2deg(xtile: int, ytile: int, zoom: int) → tuple[float, float][source]

Code for converting tile number to lat lon from https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Slippy_map_tilenames

Parameters:

  • xtile – The tile x coordinate

  • ytile – The tile y corrdinate

  • zoom – The osm zoom level

Returns:

(latitude, longitude)

gpx_analysis.gui module

This script contains the main GUI class The AppGUI class is the only one to use outside of this class

gpx_analysis.sporting module

This module contains the functions needed for the sporting analysis eg. getting position,velocity etc. at a given time

gpx_analysis.sporting.convert_speed_units(speed: float, unit: str) → float[source]

Converts the speed from m/s to another unit

Parameters:

  • speed – The speed in m/s

  • unit – The unit to convert to either: m/s, km/h, mph, s/500m or s/km

Returns:

The speed in the new unit

gpx_analysis.sporting.get_cadence_at_time(track: Track, time: float) → float[source]

Returns the cadence on a gpx track at a given time

Parameters:

  • track – The track to get the cadence from

  • time – The time to get the cadence at

Returns:

The cadence at the given time

gpx_analysis.sporting.get_cumulative_dist_at_time(track: Track, time: float) → float[source]

Returns the cumulative distance on a gpx track at a given time

Parameters:

  • track – The track to get the cumulative distance from

  • time – The time to get the cumulative distance at

Returns:

The cumulative distance at the given time (in meters)

gpx_analysis.sporting.get_position_at_time(track: Track, time: float) → tuple[float, float][source]

Returns the position on a gpx track at a given time

Parameters:

  • track – The track to get the position from

  • time – The time to get the position at

Returns:

The lat lon position at the given time

  • track – The track to get the speed from

  • time – The time to get the speed at

Returns:

  • time – The time to get the points at

gpx_analysis.sporting.map_ranges(value: float, in_min: float, in_max: float, out_min: float, out_max: float) → float[source]

Maps a value from one range to another

Parameters:

  • value – The value within the input range

  • in_min – The lower end of the input range

  • in_max – The upper end of the input range

  • out_min – The lower end of the output range

  • out_max – The upper end of the output range

Returns:

The value mapped to the output range
